page.title: 03Local History - Buckhaven
page.content: Buckhaven, like many villages on the Fife coast, originated as a fishing village. Buckhaven means stormy sounding harbour and long before any man-made harbour was built the rocky inlets offshore made Buckhaven a natural haven. Like so many fishing villages Buckhaven grew up without any planning of the buildings, the fishermen built their houses huddled as near as possible to the sea. The red pantiled roofs, external stairs, crow stepped gables and whitewashed walls gave the village a quaint typically East Neuk of Fife appearance.In the 1900s coalmining brought increased prosperity but it also destroyed the fishing. The coal deposits destroyed the golden sands and silted up the harbour which until 100 years ago supported over 400 fishermen and more than 100 boats.
